Award.AwardTitle: Acquisition of a Bruker AXS Handheld X-ray Fluorescence Unit for Chemostratigraphic Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
0949384
Rowe

This award provides funds for a hand-held AXS X-ray fluorescence unit. The unit will be used to obtain rapid chemostratigraphic information from organic-rich mudstones. The new instrument will primarily be used to prioritize samples for more detailed laboratory analysis. Samples will be screened in the field and from a core repository. The analytical goals are to match geochemical characteristics with sedimentology and stratigraphy - with emaphasis on the Permo-Triassic Boundary in the Panthalassic and Tethyan Oceans and the Barnett Shale. The PI intends to survey rock outcroppings in order to prioritize subsequent laboratory analyses. Of particular interest is determining mudstone chemostratigraphy. The instrument will support undergraduate and graduate students, the PI and internal/external collaborators. The PI routinely uses analytical instrumentation in geochemistry coursework. This acquisition will support research training for underrepresented groups. The instrument will be housed in the UT Arlington (UTA) Geoscience Building when not being used in the core repository or in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the work we have accomplished can be broken into three parts: calibration, analysis and interpretation. The instrument awarded to the University of Texas at Arlington is the first "research-grade" instrument developed for directly, non-destructively analyzing geological materials. Previous instruments, and instruments from other vendors, are not research-grade, largely due to beam instability and the lack of spectrum analysis software. Our research group developed 90 research standards for the calibration of the instrument, with the specific intent of developing high-resolution records of paleoenvironmental change in marine strata. Essentially, our goal is to be able to analyze the geochemistry of rocks in a drill core, and to develop an understanding of the conditions under which the sediments were deposited. Through synthesis of these results with other types of data, we can further develop our understanding of how the ocean has changed over geologic time. The calibration of the instrument was the first step in the development the project.

Analysis of drill core materials is ongoing, and, depending on our specific goals, we constantly tweak our method of anlaysis. Generally, we pick out a series of drill cores that contain a specific unit (formation). We scan each of the cores at a one-foot interval (each of the scans for major and trace elements takes 3 minutes each, for a total of six minutes). SOme of the intervals in the drill cores are greater than 300 feet, requiring 300 x 6minutes = 1800 minutes of scan time (approximately 30 hours). Currently, our research group has 3 undergraduate and 5 graduate students working on projects that have drill-core analysis as a signifcant component. The three undergraduates work on the Barnett Shale, a gas-prone unit in the Fort Worth Basin of North-Central Texas. The Barnett is one of the largest gas plays in the US, and the gas play wherein most of the modern "fracing" techniques were initially developed. The five graduate students work on Barnett, Haynesville, Pearsall, and Wolfcamp formations of Texas---all of which are important gas and/or oil plays.

Interpretation of the geochemical data is ongoing, but much of the initial results and early interpretations have been shown at several meetings. In fact, more than 30 presentations of our group's resarch have been shown over the last year, with ten of those being student-developed poster presentations incorporating results gathered using the awarded instrumentation. Largely, the students attempt to interpret the down-core geochemical composition of each core in terms of its mineralogy, meaning that the elements that are measured can generally be attributed to occupying one or several of a simple suite of 5-6 minerals, and thus, the down-core mineralogy can be gleaned. Subsequently, the down-core changes in mineralogy can be interpreted as temporal changes in sedimentation in the ocean. In addition, there are trace elements (in particular, molybdenum and uranium) which can indicate how oxygen-rich or -poor the sediments were during deposition. Such information is important for understanding ocean circulation during the geologic past.

Two of my students and I currently have one manuscript submitted, and I am working on a second manuscript with third student.

The broader impacts of the research are largely focused on developing students' experiences and providing unique research foci that 1) take them in a non-traditional direction, but 2) provide a skill set that is currently lacking but in much need in industry. Four of the eight students who have used the awarded instrument for their research currently possess internships and/or temporary long-term jobs that can be directly attributed to their geochemical research involving drill cores of gas-prone and/or oil-prone shales.
